rise.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to increase in number, amount, or value
rise.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: The divorce rate has risen steadily since the 1950s.
The police seem unable to cope with the rising tide of (=large increase in) car crime.
The number of people seeking asylum in Britain has risen sharply.
The country faces economic recession and rising unemployment.
Sales rose by 20% over the Christmas period.
The research budget rose from £175,000 in 1999 to £22.5 million in 2001.
rise.translation[0].definitions[0].note_: In everyday English, people usually say an amount or level goes up rather than rises:
Prices have gone up a lot.
rise.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: The floodwaters began to rise again.
She watched the bubbles rise to the surface.
the problems caused by climate change and rising sea levels
The road rises steeply from the village.
rise.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Then she picked up her bag and rose to leave.
He put down his glass and rose to his feet.
The chairman rose from his chair and came forward to greet her.
rise from the table/your chair etc
rise.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to become important, powerful, successful, or rich
rise.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: people who rise to the top in their chosen professions
She had joined the company as a secretary and risen through the ranks (=made progress from a low position to a high position) to become a senior sales director.
He had swiftly risen to prominence during the 1950s.
Mussolini rose to power in Italy in 1922.
He rose to the rank of major.
He rose to become chairman of the company.
rise.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: The bridge rose majestically into the air.
huge rocks rising from the sea
rise.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to be loud enough to be heard
rise.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: The sound of traffic rose from the street below.
Her voice rose above the shouts of the children.
rise.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: The sun rises in the east.
rise.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: if a feeling or emotion rises, you feel it more and more strongly
rise.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: She could sense her temper rising again.
There was an atmosphere of rising excitement in the school.
The doctor sounded optimistic and John’s hopes rose.
rise.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: if a large group of people rise, they try to defeat the government, army etc that is controlling them
rise.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: They rose up and overthrew the government.
They rose in rebellion against the king.
The prisoners rose against the guards and escaped.
rise.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: if bread, cakes etc rise, they become bigger because there is air inside them
rise.translation[0].definitions[11].defi: to get out of bed in the morning
rise.translation[0].definitions[12].defi: to come alive after having died
rise.translation[0].definitions[12].exam: On the third day Jesus rose from the dead.
rise.translation[0].definitions[13].defi: if a court or parliament rises, that particular meeting is formally finished
rise.translation[0].definitions[14].defi: if the wind rises, it becomes stronger
rise.translation[0].definitions[14].exam: The wind had risen again and it was starting to rain.
rise.translation[0].definitions[15].defi: if a river rises somewhere, it begins there
rise.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: The value of the painting has risen sharply in recent years.
House prices rose rapidly last year.
Male cancer rates rose significantly during the period 1969–78.
My salary had risen steadily each year.
The water temperature had risen slightly.
rise.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: an increase in number, amount, or value
rise.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: We are expecting a rise in interest rates.
Profits went up to £24 million, a rise of 16%.
rise.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: He’s been promised a rise next year.
The railworkers were offered a 3% pay rise.
rise.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: the achievement of importance, success, or power
rise.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: the rise and fall of the Roman Empire
Thatcher’s rise to power in the late 70s
The band’s sudden rise to fame took everyone by surprise.
rise.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: She watched the steady rise and fall of his chest.
a sudden rise in sea levels
rise.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: an upward slope or a hill
rise.translation[1].definitions[4].examp: There’s a slight rise in the road.
They topped the rise  (=reached the top of the hill) and began a slow descent towards the town.
rise.translation[1].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 1: an increase in number, amount, or value
rise.translation[1].note_box[0].sections: ADJECTIVES/NOUN + rise
sharp/steep
There’s been a sharp rise in house prices.
dramatic
The meter showed a dramatic rise in the level of radioactivity.
big/large
There has been a big rise in violent crime.
huge/massive
The result was a huge rise in unemployment.
substantial/significant
Manufacturers claimed the increase would mean a substantial rise in costs.
Wealthy Americans face a significant rise in their income tax rate.
The post-war years saw a rapid rise in prosperity.
steady
Japanese banks have been hit hard by the rise in interest rates.
a 10%/40% etc rise
The company reported an 81% rise in profits.
a price rise
The tax would result in a price rise of 6 percent for petrol.
a rent rise
Tenants face huge rent rises.
a temperature rise
They predicted a global temperature rise of 2.5 degrees by the end of the century.
a rise in the number of something
There has been a rise in the number of arrests for drug offences.
rise.translation[1].note_box[1].heading: – Meaning 3: the achievement of importance, success, or power
rise.translation[1].note_box[1].sections: They were alarmed by Hitler’s rise to power.
His rise to prominence would not have been possible without the war.
Her success in the film ensured a rapid rise to fame.
In this book, he explores the actor’s rise to stardom.
His rise to the top of the Labour Party was effortless.
the rise and fall of somebody/something
The exhibition tells the story of the rise and fall of the Etruscan civilisation.
What can explain their meteoric rise in popularity?
Her rapid rise to the top is well deserved.
rise.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: to increase in number, amount, or value
rise.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: House prices are likely to rise towards the end of this year.
Sales rose by 20% over the Christmas period.
As more foreign banks have arrived in Singapore, wages for experienced staff have risen sharply.
Their salaries will continue to rise steadily until they reach the top of their professions.
Information technology has been blamed for rising unemployment.
Rising prices are seen as a threat to living standards.
rise.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: to start working for an organization in a low-paid job, and to gradually improve your position, until you get a very important, well-paid job
rise.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: She had risen through the ranks, having joined the company as a secretary after she graduated from high school.
rise.translation[2].definitions[2].defin: to be very successful and reach a top position in your job or the type of business you are involved in
rise.translation[2].definitions[2].examp: An agency is where you will have the biggest chance of rising to the top in the advertising business.
rise.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: an increase in number, amount, or value
rise.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: We have sold 120,000 cars this year, a 20% rise on last year.
The company reported a 46% rise in first half profits before tax to £220 million.
A rise in taxes will be necessary if we are to improve our education system.
rise.translation[3].definitions[1].examp: After you’ve worked here for one year you get a rise.
The railworkers were offered a 3% pay rise.
rise.translation[3].definitions[2].defin: the process of becoming more important, successful, or powerful
rise.translation[3].definitions[2].examp: the rise of capitalism in the country
